hints.content:
Squares always have four right $(90^\circ)$ angles:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: This image shows the same squares as above, but now all of their vertices are labeled as right angles.

hints.content:
The angles of a triangle always add up to $180^\circ$.  Looking at the triangle with $w$ in it, this gives us:

$
\begin{align}
\qquad w^\circ + 90^\circ + t^\circ =& 180^\circ
\end{align}
$

where $t$ is the remaining angle in the triangle.  We solve for $t^\circ$:

$
\begin{align}
\qquad t^\circ =& 180^\circ - 90^\circ - w^\circ \\
\\
t^\circ =& 90^\circ - w^\circ
\end{align}
$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: This figure shows the triangles with right angles at points H and D from the figure above. The third angle in the triangle with right angle at point H is labeled to measure (90 minus 'w') degrees.

hints.content:
Vertical angles are equal, so the remaining angle in the $\alpha$-triangle is also $90^\circ-w^\circ$:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: This image shows the same two triangles from the previous image. The third angle in the triangle with right angle at point D is now shown to have a measure of (90 minus 'w') degrees.

hints.content:
The angles of a triangle always add up to $180$ degrees:

$
\begin{align}
\qquad \alpha^\circ + (90^\circ-w^\circ) + 90^\circ =& 180^\circ
\end{align}
$

We need only solve for $\alpha^\circ$.

$
\begin{align}
\qquad \alpha^\circ =& 180^\circ - 90^\circ - (90^\circ-w^\circ) \\
\\
\alpha^\circ =& 180^\circ - 90^\circ - 90^\circ +w^\circ
\end{align}
$

question.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

=====

Both square $ABCD$ and square $EFGH$ shown at left have center $Q$.  However, they do not have the same area.  Which of the following must be true?   

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: This image shows squares A B C D and E F G H, both with center at point Q but rotated in different directions so that each corner sticks out past a side of the other square. The angle between side G H and side C D measures alpha degrees. The angle between side A D and side E H measures 'w' degrees.

choices.clue: A negative angle measure is meaningless in this context.
This is the measure of an angle not asked for in the question.
This is not true since $\alpha^\circ$ and $w$ are not supplementary.
